title-group.article-title: Evaluation of Portable Household and In-Car Air Cleaners for Air Cleaning Potential and Ozone-Initiated Pollutants

abstract.p: Portable air cleaners are designed to remove airborne pollutants, but some types of air cleaners can emit or induce pollutants. This research was aimed at evaluating the performance of portable air cleaners in terms of a clean air delivery rate (CADR) for removal of fine particles and to measure ozone emission. The study was extended to investigate ozone-initiated pollutants from the use of an in-car ion generator in the presence of synthetic and natural air fresheners. The tested air cleaners included four household brands and two in-car brands. The experiments were conducted in an 8 m3 chamber. The CADRs and ozone emission rates of the tested air cleaners were determined by fitting time-dependent concentrations to mass balance models using a least-squares method. The CADRs for the household air cleaners using the HEPA and electrostatic precipitator ranged from 14 to 62 m3 h−1, while the ozone generator and the in-car ion generators were found to have negligible CADRs. The ozone generator, ion generators, and electrostatic precipitator emitted ozone at the rates of 55.7, 1.94, and 0.92 mg h−1, respectively. The use of the lemon-scented air fresheners in the presence of the in-car ion generator resulted in the substantial increases of formaldehyde, acetaldehyde, acetone, and PM2.5, while screw pine leaves and camphor did not increase the pollutants.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Indoor air pollution is considered one of the top five environmental health risks according to the US Environmental Protection Agency [1]. There are a variety of air pollutants that can affect human health. These include combustion-generated pollutants, formaldehyde, volatile organic compounds (VOCs), particles, asbestos, and radon. Ongwandee et al. [2] conducted a questionnaire survey on investigation of indoor environmental quality issues in 12 office buildings in Bangkok, Thailand. The most reported indoor air complaint was dust and dirt with a rate of 40%, which is considered higher than normal. To mitigate these indoor air contaminants, there are three principal measures generally employed: source control, ventilation and air cleaning. Among these, air cleaning devices are becoming more and more popular in households and offices. There has also been an increase in the use of air cleaning devices in vehicles that can be attributed to people’s concern over indoor air quality and the influence of heavy advertisement on the effectiveness of air cleaning devices. In Thailand, the total market value of air cleaning device was as high as 2500 million baht [3], while Shaughnessy and Sextro [4] reported that 3 of 10 American households have an air cleaning device.

Air cleaners can be classified into three types of filters: mechanical filters, electronic air cleaners and ozone generators [5]. Mechanical filters remove particles by drawing the air through filter fibres such as high efficiency particulate air (HEPA) fibres. Electronic air cleaners employ electric field to capture charged particles similar to electrostatic precipitators used in industrial gas cleaning. Due to the ionizing process, small amounts of ozone are produced. Ozone generators work by producing ozone to react with gaseous contaminants. However, ozone does not effectively clean indoor air. Ozone itself is an irritant to the nose, throat and lungs [6]. Berg [5] reported that, although using ozone can reduce some indoor air pollutants, other pollutants could be produced. Reactions of ozone with terpenoids, which are active ingredients in cleaning products and air fresheners, could produce carbonyls, organic acids, hydrogen peroxide, hydroxyl radical and secondary organic aerosol [7].

The US Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers (AHAM) developed the performance metric for measuring the ability of portable household electric room air cleaners to reduce particles from a specific size room, called Clean Air Delivery Rate (CADR) [8]. CADR is defined as “the rate of contaminant reduction in the test chamber when the unit is turned on, minus the rate of natural decay when the unit is not running, multiplied by the volume of the test chamber”. CADR is considered a simple tool to compare the performance of room air cleaners. Many researchers have adopted the CADR metric to evaluate the performance of air cleaners for removal of indoor particles [9–12]. Mullen et al. [11] measured CADRs for five commercial ion generators and one HEPA filter. The CADRs for 0.1–1 µm particles was approximately 10–80 m3 h−1 for the ion generators, while the CADR for the HEPA filter was 2.5–20 times greater. The ozone emission rates from the ion generators were between 2.7 and 4.0 mg h−1.

Besides household air cleaners, plug-in air cleaners for cars are also becoming more popular among Thai people living in the city because of an increased concern of passenger exposure to air contaminants. Most in-car air cleaners work by an ionizing process of which power is supplied via a car cigarette lighter socket. These plug-in air cleaners are sometimes used in the presence of car air fresheners. However, there is still no evaluation of plug-in air cleaners for their ability to reduce fine particles and for generation of ozone-initiated secondary pollutants due to use of synthetic and natural air fresheners. Therefore, the objective of this study is to evaluate the performance of portable air cleaners, including household and in-car air cleaners for removals of PM2.5 and PM10. The study is also extended to investigate levels of ozone-initiated carbonyls and particles while using an in-car air cleaner in the presence of various air fresheners.

sec.title: Air Cleaners Tested and Experimental Setup
sec.p:
Six different commercial brands of portable air cleaners, which are domestically sold in Thailand, were selected for this evaluation. They were newly purchased. Four of them (HEPA1, HEPA2, ESP, and OZ) were designed to be used in residence and the other two (IG1, IG2) were used in cars. Particle removal mechanisms of the selected air cleaners worked by HEPA filters (HEPA1 and HEPA2), electrostatic precipitator (ESP), ozone generator (OZ), and ion generators (IG1 and IG2). Other specifications are detailed in Table 1. Note that HEPA2 used two mechanisms for particle removal, i.e., HEPA filter and built-in ion generator. Thus, it was tested for the air cleaning potential in two scenarios: (1) when HEPA2 operated with only HEPA filter (HEPA2 OFF) and (2) when HEPA2 operated with both HEPA filter and ion generator (HEPA2 ON). CADRs for PM2.5 and PM10 and ozone emissions were measured in a sealed, aluminium sheet lined chamber with the dimensions of 2 × 2 × 2 m3. No regulated air flow was introduced into the chamber. A small fan with low rotating speed was installed at the center of the chamber roof to provide a well-mixed core and to generate an air velocity of less than 0.1 m s−1, which is a typical velocity in residential environments. The tested air cleaner was evaluated individually in the chamber, except that two sets of the in-car air cleaners were placed in the chamber. Air sampling tubes for particles and ozone were placed approximately 0.3 m away from the tested air cleaner and 0.5 m above the floor. The test chamber was installed in a highly ventilated room to prevent accumulation of pollutants outside the chamber. Prior to the experiments, the background concentrations of PM and ozone were measured below 0.05 mg m−3 and 3 ppb, respectively.

PM2.5 and PM10 concentrations were measured with a DUSTTRAK™ II aerosol monitor (Model 8530, TSI Inc., USA). The instrument employs a light-scattering laser photometer for measuring aerosol mass concentrations. The detection concentration ranges from 0.001 to 400 mg m−3. A sampling tube was inserted to the chamber with an air sampling flow rate of 0.18 m3 h−1. In this study the tested particles were generated by burning an incense stick. The ratio of PM2.5 to PM10 mass concentrations from the incense burning was approximately 96%. This ratio was similar to the PM2.5/PM10 ratios of the mosquito coil burning in an environmental chamber reported by Lee and Wang [13]. They found the variation of the PM2.5/PM10 mass ratios from 86.15 to 95.01%, suggesting that PM2.5, which was referred to as the fine fraction of PM10, was the dominant particulate matter emitted. Incense and mosquito coils are produced with a similar purpose to combust completely for a smouldering effect.

For ozone measurement, a UV absorption ozone analyzer (Model 400 E, Teledyne API, USA) was used. The lower detectable limit (LDL) was <0.6 ppb or 1.27 µg m−3 at STP. The air sampling flow rate was 0.048 m3 h−1. All data were collected and recorded every 60 s. A relative humidity probe (HI 9564, Hanna Instruments, USA) was inserted into the chamber for temperature and relative humidity measurements. The experimental temperature and relative humidity were 23–25℃ and 64–75%, respectively.

sec.title: Chamber Leakage
sec.p: A leakage of the chamber was determined using CO tracer gas decay [14]. A pulse input of CO was introduced to the chamber. The chamber was then sealed and the outlet concentration was measured with a Testo® 454 equipped with an ambient CO probe (Testo AG Inc., Germany). The determined chamber leakage was 0.014 ± 0.001 h−1.

sec.title: Loss Rate Coefficients of PM
sec.p:
Apart from particle removal by an air cleaner, other loss rates include deposition to surfaces. Generally, loss rates are linearly related to the concentration, they can be combined into the loss rate coefficient, kloss [15]. To determine the values of kloss for PM2.5 and PM10, particles were generated by burning an incense stick in the chamber to achieve an initial concentration of 0.4–0.9 mg m−3, and then the burning incense was removed. The particle concentrations were continuously monitored until the concentrations decreased to the background level. The air cleaner was not installed in the chamber. The mass balance of particles in the bulk gas phase in the chamber can be written as the following equation: (1)dCdt=λCout-λC-klossC
where C is the particle concentration in the chamber (mg m−3); Cout is the particle concentration outside the chamber (mg m−3); λ is the air exchange rate due to the chamber leakage and air sampling flow rate of the PM monitor (0.014 + 0.18/8 = 0.036 h−1). If the particle concentration outside the chamber is negligible comparing with the concentration inside, then Cout = 0. The solution to equation (1) is given by equation (2): (2)C=C0exp [-(λ+kloss)t ]
where C0 is the initial concentration of either PM2.5 or PM10 (mg m−3). The values of kloss for PM2.5 and PM10 were obtained from fitting time-dependent concentrations of PM2.5 and PM10 to equation (2). As a result, the kloss values were found to be 0.53 ± 0.03 h−1 for PM2.5 and 0.81 ± 0.01 h−1 for PM10. These experimental values are comparable with those obtained from the analysis by Lai and Nazaroff [15] using the models to calculate kloss as a function of particle diameter and friction velocity. They are in the acceptable range of 10−2 to 10−1 h−1.

sec.title: CADRs
sec.p:
To measure the CADRs, particles were generated in a similar fashion to the kloss experiment. After the burning incense was removed, the tested air cleaner installed inside the chamber was then switched on. The particle concentrations were continuously monitored for 1–34 h to obtain an adequately dynamic change for parameter quantification. Applying a non-steady state mass balance of particles in the chamber air yields equation (3): (3)dCdt=λCout-λC-QdeviceηVC-klossC
where Qdevice is the volumetric flow rate through the air cleaner (m3 h−1); η is the removal efficiency of the air cleaner; and V is the chamber volume (m3). As defined previously, CADR = Qdeviceη. If Cout = 0, then the solution to equation (3) is given by equation (4): (4)C=C0exp [- (λ+CADRV+kloss )t ]
The CADRs of the air cleaner for PM2.5 and PM10 were obtained from fitting time-dependent concentrations of PM2.5 and PM10 to equation (4).

sec.title: Ozone emission
sec.p:
Ozone emission rates were determined by operating the air cleaner in the chamber and monitoring an increase of ozone concentration in the chamber air. Applying a non-steady state mass balance of ozone in the chamber air yields equation (5): (5)dCdt=λCout-λC-νdAVC+EV
where C is the ozone concentration in the chamber (mg m−3); Cout is the ozone concentration outside the chamber (mg m−3); λ is the air exchange rate due to the chamber leakage and air sampling flow rate of the ozone analyzer (0.014 + 0.048/8 = 0.020 h−1); νd is the deposition velocity of ozone in the chamber (m h−1); A is the chamber surface area (m2); E is the ozone emission rate generated from the air cleaner (mg h−1). If the initial ozone concentration inside the chamber is negligible, then the solution to equation (5) is given by equation (6): (6)C=(λVCout+E)λV+νdA [1-exp (- (λ+νdVA )t ) ]

The parameter νd was determined by introducing pulsed ozone generated from an ozone generator to the chamber until the initial ozone concentration was 0.2–0.4 mg m−3 and then monitoring a decrease of ozone concentration. In this test the air cleaner was not installed inside the chamber. The determined value of νd was 0.084 m h−1. Quantification of E was done by fitting time-dependent concentrations of ozone generated from the air cleaner to equation (6). A nonlinear regression program, NLREG® version 6.3 (Advanced) (Phillip H. Sherwood, USA) was adopted to determine all modelled parameters.

sec.title: Air Cleaner in the Presence of Air Fresheners
sec.p:
Only IG1, an in-vehicle air cleaner, was tested for ozone-initiated pollutants in the presence of six different air fresheners. They included four commercial air fresheners used in cars, camphor contained in a mulberry bag, which is favourably used in cars and closets in Thailand, and fragrant screw pine leaves (Pandanus amaryllifolius Roxb.), which has been popularly used in Thai taxies. Characteristics and evaporation rates of the tested air fresheners are presented in Table 2. The evaporation rates were determined by placing the air freshener in a controlled temperature room at 25℃ for 24 h. Note that the active ingredients of the commercial air fresheners (solid and liquid AFs) were in their original supplier-labelled containers when performing all tests. The relatively high evaporation rate of screw pine leaves could be due to loss of water from the leaves. Table 2

Experiments were conducted under the same environmental conditions as the CADR experiments. The chamber was firstly cleaned with a terpene-free cleansing agent and then washed out with tap water and deionised water. The chamber was then dried out using a fan, overnight. The test was divided into three phases. In the first phase (AC phase), two sets of IG1 were running in the absence of an air freshener. Air samples were taken for PM2.5, ozone, and carbonyls for 2 h for reference concentrations. Next, the chamber door was opened and vented for 5 h to remove the generated ozone. In the second phase (AF phase), two samples of the tested air freshener were placed at 0.2 m above the floor of the chamber while the air cleaner was not operating. Levels of PM2.5, ozone, and carbonyls were measured for 2 h. In the last phase (AC/AF phase), the air cleaners were running in the presence of the air freshener. Note that IG1 operated with an ozone generation mode for the first 15 min, and later the air cleaning mode was switched automatically to an ion generation mode. Levels of PM2.5, ozone and carbonyls were measured for another 2 h.

Formaldehyde, acetaldehyde and acetone were collected with cartridges filled with 60/80 mesh dinitrophenylhydrazine (DNPH) coated silica gel (SKC Inc., USA). The cartridge incorporated an ozone scrubber to prevent carbonyls losses on the silica gel surface. A personal sampling pump (SKC Inc., USA) was used to draw air at a flow rate of ∼0.012 m3 h−1. Carbonyls adsorbed in the cartridges were desorbed with 2 ml of acetonitrile (ACN) (Merck & Co., USA) and a 50 μl aliquot was then injected on high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) (Shimadzu Co., Japan) using a UV detector operating at 360 nm. A mobile phase of 60% ACN/40% water was pumped at a flow rate of 4.8 × 10−5 m3 h−1 for derivative separation in an Inertsil ODS-3 column (46 × 150 mm). Sorbent in the rear section of the sample cartridges was also analyzed with no breakthrough for all three carbonyls.

sec.title: CADRs and Ozone Emission Rates
sec.p:
The estimates of CADRs and ozone emission rates for the tested air cleaners were obtained by fitting the experimental time-dependent concentrations of particles and ozone to equations (4) and (6) using a least-squares method. Figure 1 shows the measured and modelled concentration profiles of PM10 when introducing the tested air cleaners HEPA1, HEPA2 ON, HEPA2 OFF, or ESP into the chamber. Note that the concentration profiles of PM2.5 are similar to those of PM10. Figure 1
The measured and modelled concentration profiles of PM10 for the tested air cleaners.

The experimental concentration profiles were in good agreement with the model fit with the value of R2, or proportion of variance explained, varying from 0.9267 to 0.9998. Obviously, the tested air cleaners using HEPA filters and electrostatic precipitator had the CADRs considerably higher than the ozone generator and ion generators. HEPA1 had the highest CADRs of 61.8 m3 h−1, while the CADRs for HEPA2 ranged widely from 13.8 to 25.3 m3 h−1, depending on additional use of the ion generation mode. The filtration technology for both air cleaners is HEPA, which have a filter efficiency of 99.97% for the particle size of 0.3 µm. However, the power consumption for a fan required to force room air through the filter for HEPA1 is 2.6 times higher than that for HEPA2. As a result, the CADR for HEPA1 is expected to be higher than that for HEPA2. When operating HEPA2 on both air cleaning functions (ion generation + HEPA filter), the CADRs was increased by 1.6 times for PM2.5 and 1.8 times for PM10 as running without an ion generator.

This air cleaner type combines characteristics of both electronic air cleaner and dry filter. The ionizer built in HEPA2 is claimed to produce negative ions, which could possibly charge the approaching particles to the filter medium. In this way, it may assist in trapping the increased amount of particles. ESP also had the high CADRs of 44.8 m3 h−1 for PM2.5 and 34.3 m3 h−1 for PM10, which, is expected because it also uses a fan to draw room air through the unit.

Among the tested air cleaners, the estimates of CADRs for OZ, IG1, and IG2 were negative, indicating their negligible CADRs. OZ is an ozone generator, which is not designed to remove airborne particles. Instead, the particle concentrations in the chamber significantly increased while OZ was running. The plug-in ion generators for cars also had negligible CADRs. As the manufacture’s claims, these ion generators could produce ions by the electric needles. However, they appear to have no charged collector plates or building surfaces as a typically designed ionizer [12]. The units are not equipped with a fan used for driving air flow through the device for purification. With the air cleaner configuration, they are expected to have significantly low air cleaning efficiencies. Thus, the important removal mechanism for particles in the test chamber was likely due to natural deposition to the surfaces.

Only ESP, OZ, and IG1 emitted ozone while they were running. ESP uses a corona discharge to produce ions, which are then attached to particles. The charged particles flow into the oppositely charged collectors plates. During the ionizing process, ozone is produced [16]. Although the tested cleaner has a tray of zeolite to adsorb the emitted ozone, a small amount of ozone could still deliver to the room air at a rate of 0.92 mg h−1.

As described previously, IG1 has two air cleaning modes. It runs on an ozone generation mode for a first 15 min, and consequently it switches automatically to an ionizing mode. The ozone concentration would increase during the first 15–20 min and then decrease gradually due to deposition to the surfaces and reactions with other contaminant residues in the chamber. The quantified ozone emission rate during the ozone mode was 1.94 mg h−1, which is equivalent to an ozone emission rate from producing ∼1900 copies in an hour with a laser printer [17]. The ozone emission from OZ was found at the highest rate of 55.7 mg h−1 because it is designed to produce ozone. In this study, the ion generators (HEPA2 ON and IG2) were not found to produce ozone. Their ionizing process could not produce an adequately high energy to breakdown oxygen molecules. As expected, the HEPA filter, which employs fibrous filtration, was not found to produce any ozone.

sec.title: Air Cleaner in the Presence of Air Fresheners
sec.p:
IG1, which produces ozone during use of an ozone generation mode, was tested for generation of secondary pollutants in the presence of an individual air freshener in the test chamber. Two-hour average concentrations of the ozone-initiated formaldehyde, acetaldehyde and acetone are shown in Figure 2. Background concentrations during the solely air cleaner period and solely air freshener period are also included. Uncertainty range denotes the standard deviation from duplicate samples, except that only one sample was collected during the air cleaner period. One of the duplicate samples collected for the air cleaner + Liquid AF1 test was lost in analysis. Figure 2
Two-hour average concentrations of carbonyls in the chamber during the air cleaner IG1 phase (AC), air freshener phase (AF), and air cleaner IG1 + air freshener phase (AC/AF).

The concentrations of formaldehyde, acetaldehyde and acetone were elevated when using IG1 in the presence of solid AF1, liquid AF1, and liquid AF2. Solid AF1 and liquid AF1 released lime or lemon scent of which was from d-limonene, an active ingredient in a citrus scent [7]. d-Limonene, one of the most common terpenes, contains C = C double bonds that can react with ozone to form the primary ozonide and then decomposing to Criegee intermediates and carbonyls [18]. Furthermore, decomposition of the excited Criegee intermediates could produce radicals such as OH radical, which would further react with terpenes. Some of the reaction products of OH radical with limonene are acetaldehyde and acetone.

In this study, the concentrations measured during the AC/AF phase for Solid AF1 and Liquid AF1 were increased by 1.3–3.3 times for formaldehyde, 15–50 times for acetaldehyde, and 28–32 times for acetone from the background concentrations. Our results were similar to the study by Singer et al. [19] on the production of very volatile carbonyls from the use of cleaning products containing terpenes in the presence of ozone in a 50-m3 chamber. Their tested cleaning products included an orange oil-based degreaser, a pine oil-based general-purpose cleaner, and a plug-in scented-oil air freshener. The levels of formaldehyde and acetone were increased by 2–15 times those in the absence of ozone. They also found a substantial increase of fine particles.

For liquid AF2, the concentrations were also elevated by 1.7–23 times. Although the liquid AF2 package did not label active ingredients for its ocean scent, an increase of the carbonyl concentrations may be suggestive of the active ingredients of terpenes or terpene-related compounds such as linalool, α-terpineol, and linalyl acetate [7]. The wild flower scented solid AF2, camphor and screw pine were not found to statically increase the three carbonyls. Screw pine leaves contain a major flavouring compound of 2-acetyl-1-pyrroline (2AP) of which in part its chemical structure has a ketone functional group [20] similar to camphor. There existed no kinetic studies of ozone or OH radical reactions with 2AP or camphor. The similar structural compounds were studied by Glasius et al. [21]. The rate constants for the reactions of O3 and OH with the ketones were substantially lower than those for the reactions with terpenes.

Besides the increases of carbonyls, PM2.5 concentrations were also observed to rise from the background concentration. Figure 3 shows the mass concentration profiles of PM2.5 measured when the six air fresheners were used individually in the presence of IG1 as well as the background concentration from use of IG1 in the absence of air fresheners. Note that IG1 produced ozone in the first 15 min and later operated on an ionizing process. Figure 3
PM2.5 concentration profiles monitored during use of the air fresheners in the presence and absence of the air cleaner, IG1.

The use of solid AF1 and liquid AF1 in the presence of IG1 led to a sharp rise of PM2.5 concentrations in the first 20 min and then decreased gradually to the background level due to the depletion of generated ozone and the PM removal by the air cleaner. The peak concentrations were approximately double the background concentration. Solid AF2 and liquid AF2 also contributed to a rise of particle concentration, but not as much as did solid AF1 and liquid AF1. Coleman et al. [22] studied the formation of secondary organic aerosol from reactions of ozone with terpene-containing household products. They indicated an increase of airborne ultrafine and fine particles due to condensation of semi VOCs from the ozone-initiated pollutants. Condensable vapour then accumulates, resulting in new particle growth.

In this study, the increased concentrations of aldehydes, acetone and PM2.5, from the use of solid AF1 and liquid AF1 (Figures 2 and 3), were also reflected by the decrease of the peak ozone concentrations as shown in Figure 4. Figure 4
Ozone concentration profiles monitored during use of the air fresheners in the presence and absence of the air cleaner, IG1.

The peak concentrations of ozone measured during the tests of solid AF1 and liquid AF1 were 3.6 and 7.2 times lower than the peak concentration from use of IG1 in the absence of air fresheners, respectively. Furthermore, the ozone concentration profiles for all air freshener-presenting experiments decreased more rapidly than the profile observed from use of only IG1. The rapid decrease of ozone may be attributed to the ozone-initiating reactions with various organic compounds emitted from the air fresheners. The reactions could produce other secondary organic pollutants that were not detected by this study. OH radical, a potential oxidant, could also be formed via ozone/alkene reactions. Nazaroff and Weschler [7] reported the products of gas-phase reactions between terpenoids and the oxidants O3, OH and NO3. Besides the formation of carbonyls, the reaction products include carboxylic acids, free radicals and other short-lived, highly reactive species. Some of the oxidation products have extremely low odour thresholds, while many products are responsible for irritations.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: An investigation of the portable air cleaners reveals both the effectiveness of fine particle removal and generation of primary and secondary pollutants. Removals of PM2.5 and PM10 for the six tested air cleaners, as expressed in CADR, ranged from negligible for the ozone generator and in-car ion generators to 14–62 m3 h−1 for the HEPA filter and electrostatic precipitator. Evidently, the ozone generator was not designed for effectively removal of particle as claimed by the sales company. It would produce ozone at the rate of 55.7 mg h−1.

A simulation was additionally performed to predict a dynamic of ozone concentrations in a 50 m3 typical room with an air exchange rate of 0.5 h−1. Assuming that the ozone generator (OZ) was the only source of ozone emission and the removal mechanisms could only attributed to ventilation and deposition to room surfaces (νd). The ozone concentration would rise to nearly 0.1 ppm within 10 min. This level is high enough to cause pulmonary function effects in children [6]. The electrostatic precipitator (ESP) and the in-car ion generator (IG1) with an ozone generation mode were also found to emit ozone, at rates of 0.92 and 1.94 mg h−1, respectively. If IG1 is operating in a mid-size car with a passenger volume of 3.4 m3 [23] and having a stationary-condition air exchange rate of 1 h−1 [24], then the ozone level in the passenger cabin would increase from 0 to ∼0.06 ppm within 15 min. This predicted level would exceed the ozone emission limit of 0.050 ppm regulated by the California Air Resources Board for indoor air cleaning devices [25]. Furthermore, the emitted ozone can undergo chemical reactions in the presence of air fresheners, particularly for lime or lemon scent. Levels of carbonyls in the test chamber were elevated to 70 µg m−3 for formaldehyde, 102 µg m−3 for acetaldehyde and 100 µg m−3 for acetone. The PM2.5 concentration was also observed to increase by twice as that in the absence of the air fresheners.

As the results, consumers should be aware of selection and use of household and in-car air cleaners as they can cause potential exposure to any generated air pollutants. Avoidance of air cleaning devices employing ozone generation or ion generation is suggested. Other mechanical filters such as HEPA filters can remove particles effectively while not generating or initiating other indoor pollutants.
